Ladies' Aid Society cook book

A great way to engage in and learn much about a historical period can come from cuisine and the foods people used to prepare and eat. The Ladies’ Aid Society cook book was published by the Vincent Methodist Episcopal Church in Spokane, WA, in 1915. It is an interesting text because this is not only a cookbook but also a kind of guidebook for homemakers of the time. It is an instructional text divided into sections one might find in a typical cookbook, such as Soups, Fish, Meats, Vegetables, Bread, Relishes, Salads, Pies, Cakes, Puddings, tables of weights and measure, and Candies. An unnamed section also contains recipes for household fluids like library paste. At the end of some of these recipes, there is a name of a person who contributed the recipe to the cookbook. The original copy also contains full-page advertisements on every other page, akin to what is seen in Victorian serials, with advertisements promoting products and businesses of the local community.

We created a digital version of this text because we believe anyone interested in cuisine, food, and the history of the early 20th century would be curious about this text and to bring about a new appreciation for this unique text from the Special Collections of the University of Washington Library. If anyone wants to know how food played a role in the history and culture of the time, they would be interested in this book. Because the original text is so modern and sparse, special care was put into transcribing the text presented here as diplomatically as possible. This edition was created to provide historical recipes for readers for various purposes, be it a study of ingredients available, the culinary culture of the early 20th century, or kitchen technology. Even though the text has full-page advertisements on every other page, these have been omitted from our edition, as we felt that they were extraneous information and rather that the effort should be put into including as many recipes as possible.

-Madeleine and Moses of the UW

Table of contents

  • The Handwritten Preface

  • Soups

  • Fish

  • Meats

  • Vegetables

  • Breads

  • Relishes

  • Salads

  • Pies

  • Cakes

Handwritten Preface

Beets. sugar. milk. nuts. oranges. lemons. butter. eggs. meat. candy.

Sift baking powder in flour 5 tablespoons melted butter 1 coffee cup sugar creamed together 2 eggs nutmeg to taste 3 teaspoons baking powder heaping 2 coffee cups milk added Eggs + sugar + butter About 2 quarts flour added almost at once

Note: this section is hand written addition, and is not an official part of the printed text
Note: the list is likley a shopping list

1. Soups

NORMANDY SOUP.

One knuckle veal, 3 quarts cold water, 1 onion, ½ loaf baker’s bread, 1 quart cream, 2 tablespoonfuls butter, 2 tablespoonfuls flour. Put veal and onion on in cold water, let simmer 2 hours. Then add bread cut in slices, let simmer 2 hours longer. Remove meat and press the other ingredients through sieve. Rub butter and flour together, stir into boiling soup. Add cream, salt, and pepper.

—Mrs. M. F. Mendenhall.

SPLIT PEA SOUP.

Two cups split peas, add 3 pints water and clean piece of bacon rind or small piece of bacon or ham; teaspoon salt, pepper to taste, small onion, small carrot. Boil all at least 3 hours. If preferred run through colander.

—Mrs. John R. Corkery

GERMAN POTATO SOUP.

A 10-cent shin bone, add 4 quarts water , boil 3 hours , cool and skim off fat, then put back on stove and add small handful salt, 1 dried chili pepper or black pepper to taste, 1 large onion, 2 medium sized carrots, small amount of cabbage or turnip, some dried celery or fresh, 8 good sized potatoes. Boil all at least 1 hour and then run through colander and serve with bread croutons.

—Mrs. John R. Corkery.

Note: The "10-cent shin bone" is likley just a refrence to the expected price of the ingredient.

SHRIMP SOUP.

Scald 1 quart milk in double boiler. Add 1 tablespoonful flour, 1 yolk egg mixed with a little milk. When cooked and ready to serve add 1 cup minced shrimps, 1 tablespoon grated cheese, white 1 egg whipped, salt and pepper to taste.

—Mrs. McCreary.

2. Fish

MINCED CLAM PATTIES.

One can of minced sea clams, 2 cupfuls off cream or milk, 3 tablespoonfuls flour, 2 eggs, 1 tablespoonful butter, salt and pepper (to taste). Put in a stew pan or chafing dish the cream and clam juice and let come to a boil. Then add the eggs well beaten , salt, pepper, butter and clam meat. When this is hot thicken with the flour dissolved in a little milk or water. Pour into pastry patties and serve hot.

—Mrs. E.C. McRae.

SHRIMP PIRLEAU.

One teacup rice, ½ lb. bacon diced, 1 cup chopped onion, ½ can tomatoes, 1 lb. shrimp meat, 1 teaspoon beef extract, 1 teaspoon flour, ¼ lb. red pepper, 1 teaspoon celery seed. Cook rice until dry. Cook bacon and onion together. Then mix all together and cook one hour.

—Mrs. Bruce Blake

SALMON LOAF.

One-half cup milk, 1 can salmon, ½ cup bread crumbs, 2 eggs well beaten, little chopped parsley, little mace, salt and pepper to taste. Turn into greased mold and steam 1 hour.

—Mrs. Joseph Briggs.

SCALLOPED FISH.

Boil 2 lbs. halibut in a cloth with 1 slice onion, 1 stalk celery, 1 sprig parlsey, 1 bay leaf, 4 cloves and juice ½ lemon. Separate fish from bone. Cut in buttered baking dish with laternate layers of white sauce made of 1 cup milk, 1 tablespoon flour, 1 tablespoon butter. Heat in oven.

—Mrs. A. B. Lee

PIGS IN BLANKETS.

Sifter of flour; 4 teaspoons baking powder, 1 teaspoon salt; 2 tablespoons shortening; water or milk to make biscuit dough. Take 25 cents’ worth of link sausage and cut each link apart; roll our dough ¼ inch thick and cut in pieces; put one link of sausage in dough and cover all of sausage. Bake in oven, as biscuits. Do not place many in a pan, as they rise. Enough for 6 persons.

Note: This section is transcribed diplomatically. This recipe is misplaced in the Fish sction of the origional document, an editorial mistake as it was likley meant to be placed in the proceeding Meats section.

3. Meats

HAM EN CASSEROLE.

Select a slice of ham about 2 inches thick; dredge with flour and saute brown in its own fat. Brown 2 sliced onions in this fat, also a carrot scraped and sliced. Place the ham in the casserole, cover with the vegetables, add 1 turnip, pared and cut into small cubes. Add ½ teaspoon of pepper; then pour on a cupful of boiling water, cover and cook for 3 hours in a moderate oven; half an hour before the cooking is finished, add a cupful of strained tomatoes.

—Mrs. B. L. Jenkins

STEAMED HAM.

Steam good sugar cured ham 30 minutes to the pound. Cover on all sides with sugar. Put into baking pan and add extra sugar on top and around it. Add 1 pint of water and bake until the water and sugar have formed a thick syrup. Put ham on platter and pour the syrup over it. Surround with rings of pineapple sauted in butter. Varnish with parsley.

-Mrs. J. K. Cecil.

"DOBE" MEAT.

One large onion browned in tablespoonful of lard, 1 teaspoonful of cinnamon, 1 dozen cloves, pepper and salt to taste, ½ cup sugar, ½ cup tomatoes. Rub your pan with garlic. When onions are browned, flour your meat, put in a pan, add other ingredients and cook slowly in an over for 2 hours.

—Mrs. Newman.

CASSEROLE OF RICE AND MEAT.

Cook rice until tender in salted water. Butter a mold and line it ½ inch or more with the rice. Fill the center with the following: 2cups finely chopped cold cooked meat, 1 beaten egg, ¼ cup cracker or bread crumbs, salt, pepper, celery salt, onion juice, sage, nutmeg, or lemon juice depending on the variety of meat, hot stock or water to moisten. Pack the meat in the rice lined mold. Cover the top with riceand cover the rice with buttered paper to keep out the moisture. Steam ¾ of an hour. Serve with tomato sauce. Potato may be used in place of rice.

—Mrs. A. D. Butler.

4. Vegetables

STUFFED PEPPERS.

Six green peppers, remove seeds amd led stand in hot water ½ hour; 1 cup chopped meat or oysters, 1¼ cups bread crumbs, ½ cup tomatoes, ½ onion (chopped), 1 tablespoon parsley (chopped), salt, 1 egg. Fill peppers. Pour over stock and bake ⅓ hour.

—Mrs. Rutter.

MEXICAN CORN.

Two green peppers (chopped), ½ onion (chopped), fry in butter, then add 1 tablespoon flour, 1 egg (beaten), 1 cup milk, 1 cup corn, ½ cup Mexican beans, cooked, salt and pepper, paprika. Pour in buttered dish, covered with bread-crumbs and bake in oven ½ hour.

—Mrs. J. E. Daniel.

CABBAGE AU GRATIN.

Cut medium sized cabbage and cook in boiling salted water to cover until tender. Chop moderately and season with pepper, salt if necessary, and 1 green pepper pr pimento finely chopped. Cover with 1¼ cups thin white sauce, add 1-3 cup grated cheese, mix well and sprinkle thickly with ¾ cup buttered crumbs. Place in oven and baker until mixture is heated through and crumbs are browned.

—Mrs. Glen Powell

STUFFED PEPPERS(MEXICAN STYLE).

Parboil peppers from which seeds have been removed, stuff with cold minced meat and bread crumbs, to which add a few raisins; dot the top with butter and bake half an hour.

—Miss Mathers.

CORN PUDDING

Eight ears corn scored down center, thne scraped; 1 tablespoon butter, 1 cup milk, 1 teaspoon flour, 3 ggs beaten light. Bake ¾ hour.

—Mrs. W. S. McCrea.

SPANISH RICE.

Two slices of bacon, cut into small pieces and fried nicely brown; add 2 cups water, 1 cup rice, 1 onion, ½ can tomatoes, 1 chile pepper; cook 30 minutes.

4. Breads

CREAM DATE ROLES.

Two cups pastry flour, ½ teaspoon salt, 4 teaspoons Royal baking powder, 1 tablespoon butter, 1 cup cream (all measurements level), dates.

Process: Sift dry ingredients together; rub in butter with fingers. Add cream, mix with spatula to soft dough. Handle lightly. Roll on floured board to 1-3 inch thickness. Cut with biscuit cutter; place ½ a stoned date on ½ biscuit, brush edges with milk, and fold as Parker House rolls. Press edges together, brush top of rolls with milk, place ½ date on top. Bake about 15 minutes.

Cheese Biscuit may be made by substituting grated cheese for dates in above recipe, and are delicious.

-Mrs. E. F. Waggoner.

Note: A "Parker House roll" is a variety of bread roll made by rolling the dough into an oval shape and then folding them in half. They were invented at the Parker House Hotel in Boston in the 1870s.

BROWN BREAD

Mix together 1 teaspoonful salt, 2 teaspoonfuls soda (level), pinch ginger. Add 1 cup molasses 2 cups sweet milk, 3¼ cups graham flour, ½ cup raisins. Steam 3 hours, then bake 10 minutes.

-Mrs. Wm. Merryweather.

POTATO MUFFINS.

Two cups mashed potato, 1 cup warm milk, 1 cake compressed yeast, 2 eggs well beaten, 1 tablespoon lard, 1 tablespoon sugar, 1 teaspoon butter, salt to taste, 3 cups flour. Set then at 11 o’clock. Roll at 4 and bake at 6.

—Mrs. E. Taylor.

NUT BREAD.

One cup sour milk, 1 cup sweet milk, 2 cups whole wheat or graham flour, 1 cup white flour, 1 cup sugar (scant), 1 teaspoon baking powder, 1 teaspoon soda, 1 teaspoon salt, ½ cup raisins and ½ cup walnuts chopped.

—Mrs. W. H. Matthews.

5. Relishes

ORANGE MARMALADE.

Take 1 dozen oranges, peel very thin (cut peel fine); remove all the white and slice oranges thin, add 2 qts. of cold water. Let stand for 24 hours, cook until tender, then add 8 lbs. sugar, juice of 4 lemons and boil at least 1 hour longer.

–M. K.

Note: Interestingly, this is the only submission with a name that does not have a gendered title. All other recipes submissions with attached names have explicitly feminine titles such as miss or mrs. This segmentation is to be expected, as the setting of the early 20th century and only recent urbanization of Spokane at the time both would have reinforced more tradtional western gender roles.

PEACH CONSERVE.

Six pounds peaches (diced), 1 can pineapple (diced), 3 oranges, peel of 1 orange, 6 cups sugar. Make a thick syrup of the sugar. Into this, drop the peaches and cook for 10 minutes. Cook the orange peel until tender and shred. Then add the pineapple, oranges and peel to the peaches, and cook for 5 minutes more.

-Mrs. J. D. Ellis.

RHUBARB CONSERVE.

Five pounds rhubarb, 5 lbs. sugar, 3 oranges, 1 small tablespoon ground ginger, 1 lb. walnut meats. Prepare rhubarb as for stewing peel and slice oranges fine, add sugar and ginger and cook until quite thick. Take off and add the nuts (chopped). Prunes can be used instead of rhubarb. Put them through grinder before cooking.

—Mrs. Mae Jones.

INDIAN PEACH PICKLES.

Seven pounds fruit, 3 pounds sugar, 1 pint vinegar. Heat vinegar, sugar, and teaspoon whole allspice and cloves and several pieces of mace (these three spices tied in cloth), 1 tablespoon stick cinnamon. Pour over uncorked peaches, heating and pouring over peaches for 9 days. The last day cork peaches few minutes. Boil down syrup and pour over peaches.

—Mrs. A. E. Blake.

Note: It is unclear whether the term "indian" here is a refrence to the country in southern Asia or to the Indigenous peoples of the US.

GRAPE CONSERVE.

Three pints Concord grapes, 3 pints granulated sugar, 1 pint water, ½ pound seeded raisins, 2 oranges chopped fine, 1 cup chopped walnuts added last. Pulp grapes and cook pulps. Put through colander. Add skins and other inregdients and cook 1 hour.

—Mrs. May Jason.

6. Salads

PINEAPPLE AND TOMATO SALAD.

On a lettuce leaf place a ring of pineapple, then a slice of ripe tomato; put on a spoonful or two of mayonnaise dressing and garnish with a salted cherry or stuffed olive.

-Mrs. B. L. Jenkins.

POTATO SALAD.

Six large boiled potatoes cut in cubes, 1 onion cut fine, 3 hard boiled eggs chopped. Mix with this dressing ½ cup sugar, ½ cup vinegar, ½ cup water, 1 tablespoon flour, 1 tablespoon butter, 3 ggs. Mix well and cook in double boiler. When cool add cream.

-Mrs. Dana Child.

SALAD DRESSING FOR TEN PEOPLE.

One-half cup vinegar, ½ cup butter, ½ cup sugar, 4 eggs. Boil all together until thick. Add 1 cup thick, sour cream. Let stand a minute. Pour over 12 large potatoes, 8 hard-boiled eggs and 1 small onion.

FRUIT SALAD DRESSING.

One-fourth cup fruit juice (pineapple)m juice of ½ lemon, ¼ cup sugarm yolks of 2 eggs. Cook slowly and cool before serving.

-Mrs. F. H. Quilliam

Note: The seemingly put of place "m"s are present in the origional text and have been transcribed here diplomatically

HOT POTATO SALAD.

Boil 6 or 8 potatoes without paring and dice while hot; peel and chop 1 large onion and mix with potato; cut up some breakfast bacon into small bits sufficient to fill a teacup and fry it a light brown; remove the meat, and into the grease stir 3 tablespoonsful of vinegar, making a sour gravy, which, with the bacon pour over the potato and onion; mix lightly. To be eaten hot.

-Mrs. J. E. Horton.

SALAD DRESSING.

Mix together 1 teaspoon of salt, 1 teaspoon of dry mustard, 2 tablepsoons of sugar, 1 tablespoon of flour. To this add the yolks of 2 eggs, well beaten, 2 tablespoons of melted butter, 1 cup sweet milk and ½ cup vinegar, the latter added slowly. Cook in double boiler, stirring constantly until thick. This will keep for weeks.

7. Pies

PINEAPPLE PIE.

Fill a rich, flaky crust with the following: In a double boiler put the liquid of a can of shredded pineapple with two (2) cups of water, bring to a boil. Add five (5) tablespoons corn starch, dissolved in a liter of water, yolks of four (4) eggs, one and one-half (1½) cups of sugar, butter size of a walnut. When cool add the shredded pineapple. Fill crust with this mixture. Uhe the whites of the eggs for meringue, beaten with two (2) tablespoons sugar. Brown lightly in oven. This recipe makes two (2) large pies.

-Mrs. A. M. Johnson.

WALNUT PIES.

Boil together until thick, yolks of 3 eggs, 1 cup sugar, 1 cup milk, 1 heaping teaspoon flour. Let cool and add a cup of chopped walnuts, then turn into baked pie crust, use whites for top.

-Mrs. H. A. Flood.

DIVINITY PIES.

Whites of 3 eggs, beaten to a stiff froth; 1 tablespoon sugar, stirred into the whites of eggs; put eggs and sugar into the crust (baked the day before) and bake a short time; let cool, take ½ pint of whipping cream, beat to a stiffness and tdd 2 tablespoons sugar and spread over pie. Flavor to taste.

-Mrs. Glenn Russell.

APPLE CUSTARD PIE.

One cup stewed apple, mashed very fine; 2 eggs, 1 cup sugar, ⅓ cup butter. Bake with one crust and use the whites of the eggs for frosting after the pie is done. Brown nicely by returning to oven.

PUMPKIN PIE.

One and one-half cups stewed pumpkin, dry; 2 cups milk, 2 beaten eggs, ½ cup brown sugar, 1 teaspoon cinnamon, ½ teaspoon each of sale and ginger. Line pie tins and bake in slow oven.

RHUBARD PIE.

One cup rhubarb, chopped fine 1 cup sugar, 1 egg. Bake in two crusts. Flavor with lemon if desired.

Note: correction: this recipie is recorded diplomatically, including the mispelling of "rhubarb" as "rhubard"

8. Cakes

NUT CAKES.

One-half cup butter, 1 cup sugar, 3 eggs, ½ cup milk, 1¾ cups flour, 3 teaspoons baking powder, 1 teaspoon flavoring, ¾ cup of nuts (walnuts or pecans) broken in small pieces Mixin usual manner and bake in small pans.

-Mrs. Chas L. Featherstone.

DATE CAKE.

One pound dates (after stoning), 1 pound English walnut meats, 1 cup flour, 2 rounded teaspoons baking powder, ½ teaspoon salt, 1 small cup sugar, 4 eggs beaten separately, teaspoon vanilla. Bake in loaf.

-Mrs. G. W. Paine.

DELICIOUS PORK CAKE.

Two cups solid fat pork (ground fine), 2 cups boiling water (pour over pork), 2 cups sugar, 2 cups New Orleans molasses, ½ pound currants, ½ pound raisins, ¼ pound pound citron and lemon peel, 1 cup chopped nuts, 3 teaspoons soda, dissolved in boiling water, cloves, cinnamon, nutmeg, to taste. Mix quite stiff with flour and bake for 1¼ hours with a steady fire. Will keep indefinitely.

-Mrs. A. E. Keats.

Note: At the time of publication, most homes had either a wood stove or a range, which used natural or coal gas. The "steady fire" mentioned here could be in refrence to fire in a wood stove, or possibly that the submiter was invisioning that people would cook this over the hearth,, which had only recently gone out of style.
Note: The citron mentioned here was not a common ingredient, and instead other citruses like lemons or oranges were commonly used. When citrons are mentioned though, it is often candied or in sweeter baked goods such as this.

SPICE CAKE.

One egg, 1 cup sugar, ½ cup butter, 1 cup sour milk, 1 teaspoon soda, 2⅔ cups flour, all spices as desired.

-Mrs. Z. Stewart.

AUNT EMMA'S FRUIT CAKE.

One and one-half cups light brown sugar, ⅔ cup butter, 2 eggs, ½ cup sour milk, scant 2½ cups flour, ⅔ cup raisins, ⅔ teaspoon soda, 2 tablespoons cut citron or ¼ cup chopped nuts.

-Mrs. Emma Till.

Appendix A

  2. Michael Umphrey Foodways in 1910 The Montana Heritage Project 2004
  3. Frances Stern and Gertrude Spitz Food for the Worker Witcomb and Barrows 1917 Boston
  4. Amelia Simmons American Cookery Hudson and Goodwin Hartford 1796
